stream_context.summary: Kaze polishes and redesigns a sky area in Course 1 to feel more "Yoshi’s Island" (switching from blocky visuals to a birdhouse theme), tunes visual fog/fading for background trees, implements a major physics tweak to Mario 64’s slide speed cap, and outlines a plan to ship a Course 1 demo focused on collecting player feedback about new camera/physics via a questionnaire. He also prototypes replacing a pipe/teleport with a Yoshi’s Island-style growing flower/vine interaction to guide players to the slide entrance.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete plans for a feedback-driven demo release, a meaningful physics change (slide speed soft-cap), and a key design direction shift toward stronger Yoshi’s Island theming (birdhouse + growing flower mechanic), plus collaboration points with Biobak/Lilaa.

findings.summary: Kaze decides the sky area should be redesigned into a Yoshi’s Island-themed "birdhouse" to replace what he calls "Minecraft blocks" and mismatched colors, aiming for a more cohesive, warm, storybook aesthetic (start/end in a birdhouse).
findings.quote: This is Yoshi's Island. Let's make this look like a birdhouse. You start in a birdhouse, you end in a birdhouse.

findings.summary: Kaze changes SM64 sliding physics: instead of a hard cap at 100 speed (which instantly deletes excess velocity), he adds a soft cap around 95 where speeds above 95 decay asymptotically (~5% per frame), preserving high entry speed while keeping normal slide feel.
findings.quote: In vanilla Mario 64 the sliding is hard capped at 100 speed... I soft capped it at 95... when you slide on with a lot of speed, you will keep that speed.

findings.summary: He outlines a structured demo plan: release a demo containing only Course 1 specifically to gather data on new physics and camera behavior, shipping it with a Google Doc questionnaire asking about autorotate, pan speed, pitch limits/default pitch, feel of physics, and bugs.
findings.quote: I am thinking of releasing a demo with just course 1... we want reviews from the player... together with a questionnaire.

findings.summary: Demo timing is tied to Kaze’s YouTube pipeline: one video in ~2 weeks, another in ~4–5 weeks, and the demo targeted around ~8 weeks maximum (ideally 3–4 weeks if possible).

Kaze prototypes replacing a pipe-based route/teleport with a Yoshi’s Island-inspired "growing flower" interaction to make the slide entrance easier to find and more diegetic; goal is to remove an existing sign because players struggled to locate the slide.
findings.quote: People had trouble finding the slide here. To the point where I put up a stupid sign here. And I guess I can remove the sign now.

findings.summary: He proposes an interaction design for the flower: the bud subtly animates faster as Mario approaches; a nearby bunny provides an optional hint; Mario uses a Bowser-style grab/pull animation (stick back or mash) to yank the bud, which then rapidly grows into a climbable structure with leaves—trying to keep it readable without forcing dialogue/tutorialization.

Kaze articulates a guiding constraint: even when adding puzzle-like interactions, it must feel natural in Mario 64 rather than contrived, and levels should ideally be beatable without talking to NPCs (dialogue should be optional).
findings.quote: You can't just turn it into puzzles. You have to make it feel really natural... ideally, this level should be beatable without ever talking to anyone.

findings.summary: He describes practical N64 rendering constraints driving art choices: HD textures cost ROM space but can be manageable (he cites a 16-texture set totaling ~36 KB), and background fades require back-to-front draw ordering when there’s no Z-buffer; he considers HUD-style cutout rendering tricks using shade alpha + primitive alpha to fade objects into fog.
Kaze reiterates a core structural decision: the hack will have a large hub world because it "glues the whole game together" (framing the project as a cohesive adventure rather than isolated courses).
findings.quote: A hub world is very important... it's gluing the whole game together.

findings.summary: He confirms a collection/mission structure change: the hack removes 100-coin stars, replacing them with Yoshi-coin-style collectibles (e.g., collect six) that can be gathered during other missions without losing progress.
findings.quote: There's no more 100 coin star... it's replaced by Yoshi coins... they can be collected anytime while you're doing another mission.

findings.summary: Kaze notes his debugging workflow: for difficult code bugs he uses NEMU (assembly-level inspection) and mentions a GDB extension he hasn’t set up yet; he briefly struggles with emulator stability/flicker when switching tools (Project64/RS).

Kaze shares personal context affecting production: he has a newborn daughter (about 4 weeks old), which makes scheduling harder; he also mentions recent stress/brain fog and frustration with software changes (new Blender behavior).
findings.quote: If you haven't noticed, I have a small child. That makes planning things really difficult.

biobak.summary: Biobak gives actionable art-direction feedback: improve depth/fog by duplicating tree layers and fading them (whiter/more transparent) so trees recede into fog; Kaze implements and praises the result.
Biobak reacts to Kaze’s color/brightness adjustments (e.g., "too dark at the top"), helping iterate on readability and mood in the sky area.

findings.summary: Kaze calls out a "Fast64 mover"/snapping issue and asks Lilaa to fix it, implying Lilaa supports tooling/pipeline troubleshooting for level editing.

Kaze references Discord staff discussing harassment from a previously banned community member (Skillenio) targeting Lilaa, highlighting ongoing moderation/scene baggage that occasionally intersects with development streams.
Kaze attributes the disliked "Minecraft blocks" visual idea to Violet, then chooses to move away from it toward a more Yoshi’s Island-consistent birdhouse look.

key_stories.title: Course 1 demo planned as a physics/camera playtest
key_stories.summary: Kaze frames the next public release as a demo containing only Course 1, explicitly to validate new physics and camera behavior. He plans to attach a questionnaire to turn player reactions into actionable tuning data, and he sketches a rough timeline tied to upcoming videos.
key_stories.challenge: Risk of shipping a full game with camera/physics choices players dislike or find uncomfortable; need structured feedback early.
key_stories.process: Limit scope to Course 1; draft targeted questions (autorotate, pan speed, pitch ranges, default pitch, physics feel, bugs); aim release timing around the video schedule.
key_stories.outcome: Demo is planned (target 3–8 weeks), with a deliberate feedback pipeline to guide iteration before full release.
key_stories.key_quote: I want more data on gameplay... so that when I release the full game, we know for sure people like the camera and the physics.

key_stories.title: Re-theming the sky area into a birdhouse to better match Yoshi’s Island
key_stories.summary: Kaze critiques the current sky area’s color harmony and blocky look, and decides to re-theme it as a birdhouse environment to strengthen the Yoshi’s Island identity. Visual iteration includes skybox improvements and fog/depth tweaks to background trees with Biobak’s feedback.
key_stories.challenge: Area feels visually incoherent ("random color pixels" / "Minecraft blocks") and not aligned with the warm Yoshi’s Island vibe.
key_stories.process: Commit to a birdhouse motif; adjust background tree fading and layering; fix UV mapping in the slide region to improve movement feel and visuals.
key_stories.outcome: A clearer art direction is chosen, and background depth is improved; further color/palette work remains.
key_stories.key_quote: This is Yoshi's Island. Let's make this look like a birdhouse.

key_stories.title: Replacing a pipe/teleport with a Yoshi’s Island-style growing flower route
key_stories.summary: To reduce confusion about how to reach the slide entrance, Kaze explores replacing a pipe with an interactive flower bud that grows into a climbable structure, inspired by Yoshi’s Island. He debates readability (players must understand ‘pull’ without forced dialogue) and considers animation/audio cues plus an optional bunny hint.
key_stories.challenge: Players struggled to find the slide, requiring an inelegant sign; a pipe implies teleportation rather than a natural in-world traversal.
key_stories.process: Prototype a large flower/vine climb; test how annoying it is to ascend; pivot toward an auto-rising/spinning ‘elevator’ behavior; plan a fog fade-out at the top using N64-friendly alpha tricks.
key_stories.outcome: Direction shifts toward an automatically moving climbable plant and removing the sign/pipe; final implementation details (pull interaction, animations, fade rendering) are pending.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem is, how do you make the player know that they have to pull on it?

open_questions.topic: Course 1 demo questionnaire and feedback loop
open_questions.context: Kaze wants to ship a Course 1 demo plus a questionnaire focused on camera/physics (autorotate, pan speed, pitch limits/default pitch, physics feel, bugs). He jokes about using ChatGPT to rewrite questions because players won’t know terms like "pitch."
questions: What specific camera system is being evaluated in the demo (autorotate rules, default pitch, min/max pitch), and what prior playtest feedback prompted these categories?
How will Kaze triage and translate questionnaire responses into concrete parameter changes (e.g., thresholds for changing pan speed or pitch ranges)?
Will the demo include instrumentation (auto-collected metrics) or rely purely on self-reported feedback and bug reports?

open_questions.topic: Final design for the growing flower/vine interaction (readability vs. complexity)
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a flower bud that reacts to proximity, optional bunny hinting, and a Bowser-style pull interaction, but receives pushback that it may be annoying/complicated. He then pivots toward an automatically rising/spinning plant to reduce climbing frustration.
questions: Which version shipped/was kept: manual pull-to-grow, auto-rising elevator plant, or another solution entirely?
How did Kaze ensure players discover the interaction without mandatory NPC dialogue (visual language, sound cues, sign replacement, camera framing)?
Did this mechanic become a recurring traversal language across multiple levels/overworld, and if so, how was it tutorialized without breaking immersion?

open_questions.topic: N64 rendering approach for fog fade-out of the plant
open_questions.context: Kaze discusses fading geometry into fog without Z-buffer issues and considers a HUD-style cutout approach using shade alpha gradients combined with primitive alpha thresholds.
questions: What exact rendering pipeline did Kaze implement for the fade (combine modes, 1-cycle/2-cycle, cutout threshold logic), and what tradeoffs did it impose on leaf visuals?
Did the fade approach become a reusable technique for other tall/background objects in RTYI?

open_questions.context: Kaze states there are no 100-coin stars and that progress-friendly Yoshi coins (collect six) replace that role, collectible during other missions.
questions: What design problems with 100-coin stars was Kaze targeting (pacing, repetition, route constraints), and how did Yoshi coins solve them?
How are Yoshi coins integrated into mission structure and difficulty balancing (placement rules, per-course count, reward cadence)?

open_questions.topic: Collaboration workflow with Biobak and tooling pain points
open_questions.context: Biobak provides real-time art feedback on fogging/trees; Kaze calls out Fast64 snapping/mover issues to Lilaa and complains about Blender behavior changes affecting modeling/edge splitting.
questions: What is the actual division of labor and handoff process between Kaze (implementation), Biobak (art/level feedback), and tool-support contributors like Lilaa when a tool bug blocks progress?
How often do external tool updates (Blender/Fast64/emulators) force pipeline changes, and what safeguards (version pinning, exporters, validation checks) does the team use now?
